SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: H. C. Young
Address: Redvers
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ..... 1879
Where did you set up housekeeping? ..... Ross District, Man.
Where had you been living before that? ..... Worthington
For how many people did you prepare meals? ..... 6
How far was it to your nearest store? ..... 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? ..... Once a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Evaporated apples, prunes, rolled oats, tea, coffee, corn syrup, butter, cheese, canned beef, salmon.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ..... Hungarian Patent (so called)
In what quantities did you buy it? ..... 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ..... 2.60
How much did you use graham flour? ..... 100 lbs
Whole wheat flour? ..... Yes
Was flour milled locally? ..... Yes
How far away? ..... 5 miles
What year? ..... 1901
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ..... 3.50
What other grain products did you use? ..... Bran
Cornmeal? ..... No
Whole Wheat? ..... No
Farina? ..... No
Other? ..... None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ..... No
How did you grind it? ..... Mill at Headingley, Man., near Winnipeg

Handwritten answers:

- What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1879
- Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina, Saskatchewan
- Where had you been living before that? Medicine Hat
- For how many years did you live there? 5
- How far was it to your nearest store? Cross a road
- How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
- What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries, Butter, Cheese, Bread, Beef, Salmon, Coffee, Tea

Handwritten answers continued:

- What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Armstrong's (noted)
- In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
- What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $6.00
- How much did you use graham flour?
- Whole wheat flour?
- Was flour milled locally? Yes
- What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
- What other grain products did you use? None
- Cornmeal?
- Other?
- Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
- How did you grind it? Hand grinding by hand, then winnowing
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lb. each
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 75¢
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Crown Brand
What size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb. 6 oz.
At that price? 75¢

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Not sure
Did you have any neighbors who had cows?
What was the price of butter? 15¢
Did you pick eggs for yourself? Yes
Did you make butter? No
Did you make cheese? Yes
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Salt pork, bacon, beef
How did you get fresh meat? From a neighbor
How often did you get fresh meat? 1/4 of beef for Winter
How did you preserve meat? Bought a pig and salted meat
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes
If so, what year was it organized? After 1914
Did you use game? Not much
What kinds? Ducks, rabbits
For how long? 6 years
What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned
Kinds? Salmon
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Various At what price? 3 lbs 1.00
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? None
What other beverages were used? None

7. VEGETABLES AND MIXED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 5 cts
Could you get potatoes at the store? No
If not, where from? Neighbors
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1906 Cabbage Carrots 1906 Onions
Turnips 1906 Beets 1916
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? None
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box 10 lbs
What weight? 10 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Mostly bulk various sizes
What was the price of prunes? 2 lbs 25 cts
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No
Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?
Other foods?
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?
What year did you first preserve meat by canning?
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? No
To what extent?
Did you make your own vinegar? No

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast Porridge fried pork potatoes apple sauce

Dinner Eggs & fried pork, potatoes, pie

Supper Eggs boiled or fried, potatoes, cake, pie

Pruers Evap apples or apricot sauce

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1897

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Man I was working for and his wife young people

we lived well much the same as now

Turkey was cheap 1$ each

Fresh Meat in Winter only Salt pork in Summer

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Always had enough in early days

There were no competing scales. No oil pumps. Kerosene measured out. No cash registers or adding machines. Plug tobacco cut with knife. Tea sold in bulk but not tobacco - no copper cents used. Everything cheaper many things better quality than now.

Apples from East in barrels no less from BC.

Difficult third of frozen dogs. Candies in wooden tubs in early days.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Women baked bread and everything else made butter, dressed chickens etc. Very little canned goods only salmon sometimes no store jam. Cook apples, prunes, apricots, no wild fruit used in our part. When prairie fires quiet and bluffs grew up. Saskatchewan & Choke Cherry.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

No canned goods except beef and salmon.
